BCS Parents,

This is not a test. This is our future.

A kindergartener counted in the 2020 Census will be in high school when the next census comes around in 2030. That’s 10 years of community programs that benefit our state. Did you know that Alabama receives $13 billion a year to fund programs like nutrition, healthcare, transportation, roads, recreation centers, police, firefighters, and
more? This is your opportunity to help ensure our kids have a bright future.

Students are learning these key things about the 2020 Census and we want you to know them too:
*Everyone living in your home needs to be counted. That includes children, babies, grandparents, and even those staying with you temporarily. They all count.
*It’s easier than ever to respond to the Census. Complete it online at my2020census.gov or call 844-330-2020. It only takes about 6 minutes.
* Your responses are safe and secure. The law requires the U.S. Census Bureau to keep your information confidential.

You have the power to shape your future—and the future of Alabama’s children—by counting everyone in your home by September 30th.

Census Pledge:
I pledge to count my family.
I pledge to let my voice be heard.

Click the link and complete the census: my2020census.gov

post_text:
Hello Bessemer City Parents:

We are super excited to welcome our students back SOON!

If you watched the live stream of the Board meeting last night, there was mention of a delayed student start date. Our revised calendar is scheduled for Board approval during the next board meeting. Based on the calendar, the student start date will be Thursday, September 3, 2020. Your Principal can answer any questions regarding the proposed calendar. A copy will be shared with you once it has been Board approved. Please read the attached newsletter for more information.

At the request of Board members, we have made the decision to start the first nine-week grading period online. The first nine weeks will be fully online for all students. We will continue to assess where we are as it relates to COVID at the midpoint. The plan has been revised to reflect the first nine-weeks as the remote learning model.

Please read the attached newsletter for a full overview and updates. Parents will receive a condensed version of the plan presented during the Called Board Meeting this week. As always, reach out to your child's school if you have questions or email us at bcsparents@bessk12.org.

"Progress is IMPOSSIBLE without change. Change makes us grow."
-------------------------------
Duane Edward Hale is an Alabama Native as he prepares to enter his 19th year in public education in which he has served communities in the states of Alabama and Georgia. Duane has been able to grow professionally through his service roles as a teacher, content chairperson, athletic coach and director, assistant principal, and principal. Duane just completed his fourth year as principal at his alma mater, Wilcox Central High School (WCHS), in which WCHS experience an 11-point increase on the Alabama Department of Education Report Card Index

during his tenure.

Duane received a Bachelor's Degree (B.S.) in Elementary Education and a Master’s Degree (M.Ed.) in Educational Administration from The University of West Alabama. Mr. Hale also obtained an Educational Specialist (E.D.’s) in Curriculum and Instruction from Lincoln Memorial University and currently enrolled in the Kennesaw State University Doctoral Program in Teacher Leadership.

Additionally, Duane considers himself to be an innovator who can inspire students, families, teachers, faculty, and staff with a sense of self-worth while working together cooperatively and collectively to prepare students for their choice of college and career pathways. Duane is genuinely excited about the opportunity to be of service to the students, parents, faculty, staff, and communities of Bessemer City High School during the 2020-2021 academic year.

Furthermore, Duane believes that a safe and secure learning environment is necessary for children to learn effectively from a philosophical standpoint. Further, Duane thinks that rigorous instruction and active engagement are the foundations of quality 21st-century education. By setting high expectations and challenging students to meet them, Bessemer City High School will continue to grow as a learning community.

Finally, Mr. Hale's professional motto is: "Excellence is the Only Standard," and this motto will drive the daily mission and vision at Bessemer City High School as all faculty, staff, and community stakeholders work together collaboratively to prepare all students for a better quality life and Duane's is ready for this new exciting instructional and operational journey.

Bessemer City Schools family mourns the loss of student

Bessemer — July 3, 2020 — It is with deep regret that we announce the tragic loss of Jonesboro Elementary School student, Royta Giles Jr. (pronounced Roy-TAY Jyles). The young child was killed during a shooting this afternoon at the Riverchase Galleria Mall in Hoover.

School administrators have been speaking with the child’s family members and offer support as they grieve the sudden and difficult loss. “Our hearts are simply broken at the tragic loss of Royta. We are here for the family in every way possible, and we ask that everyone lifts the mother, family, and our school community in your prayers. This is tough,” says Bessemer City Schools superintendent, Dr. Autumm Jeter.

Royta Giles was heading to the 3rd grade this fall. Principal, Dr. Anjell Edwards, and staff describe him as a smart child, who was a jewel, with big dreams of someday entering the music industry. “He was bright, articulate, and very convincing. We even tried to convince him to become a lawyer,” says former assistant principal Mr. Van James.

The school system will remain available and continue to support those within the Bessemer City Schools family by all means possible to help them through this time. Meanwhile, those without immediate relationship to the family are asked to be sensitive to this tragic situation.

All inquiries related to this press release should be directed to investigators. Thank you in advance for respecting this request, which allows the District’s attention to remain on serving the students and families of impacted by this shooting.

Dr. Corvetta V. Clasberry is a native of Birmingham, Alabama and a product of the Birmingham City School System where she graduated from West End High School as an honor student. An educator for numerous years, she has been an elementary teacher, high school assistant principal, elementary principal, and Director of Human Resources. Her goal has always been to be the best educator that she could be by inspiring students to do their best. She strives daily to make a positive difference in the lives of children.

Dr. Clasberry received the following degrees: Bachelor of Science from the University of Montevallo, Master of Education from Alabama A&M University, administrative certification, Educational Specialist, and Doctor of Education all from the University of Alabama at Birmingham. She is also a veteran of the United States Navy Reserve in which she served dutifully as a hospital corpsman.

Dr. Clasberry has touched the lives of many students over the past years. She is excited to be a part of the Bessemer City School System. One word to describe her is committed. She is committed to rendering the best educational experiences to the students of Bessemer City because they deserve it!

Dr. Clasberry is an active member of many state and national educational organizations; as well as an active member of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc. Dr. Clasberry is married and has two beautiful children.

“Education is the passport to the future, for tomorrow belongs to those who prepare for it today.” – Malcolm X.

I received my Bachelor’s of Science in Psychology with honors with a Minor in Chemistry from the University of Alabama in Birmingham (1995) and attended Miles College (1998) for my teaching certification. I began my teaching career as an Eighth Grade Science Teacher at James A. Davis Middle School in 1998.

In my 22 years of service in education, I have served as a Middle and High School Science Teacher, a Teacher Mentor to several new teachers and many other leadership roles.

As an educational leader and advocate, I have endeavored to do my best to be a life-long learner. I strive to motivate, teach, inspire, and ignite that same passion for learning in others regardless of age and background. My philosophy is to teach from the heart while allowing others to discover their own abilities to become scholars and positive role models in our community.

It is Ms. Boyd’s desire to serve as an “oasis” of resources for the students, teachers, school administration, parents and community members of Bessemer. My goal is to be “Optimistic in Applying Strategic Innovative Support” for all stakeholders.

We followed regulations for safety measures and blew lots of air hugs and kisses!!! In addition, they received lots of literature and hands-on activities to support their e-learning experience. Special thanks to all of our BESSEMER PRE-K PARENTS for being patient during this process!!! You all are the real MVPs!!! Special thanks to Ms. Rumley, Ms. Wells, and all Pre-K teachers from both schools, Hard and Jonesboro for making this task possible with your assistance and support shown for this event.

Good Morning Bessemer City School Family:

Our extended break has come to a close and we officially begin eLearning with academic packets! We want you to know that you are not alone in this eight-week journey of learning while home. Your teachers, administrators, and others in the school system are dedicated to helping you and ensuring that you succeed. Our employees know that we are “out, not off,” so feel free to reach out if you need help. Teachers will be recording lessons, doing live lessons, emailing, calling, using interactive apps, Google Classroom and engaging in virtual meetings to teach sessions. Students and parents, YOU MUST DO YOUR PART and we know that you can do it!! We are on a positive path in Bessemer City Schools, but we need you to do what you can. Check on your friends, and ask them, “have you done your schoolwork.”

Very soon we will be posting our help desk phone number and email address. You can reach us that way anytime. Look for my video messages to you each week on Facebook, Twitter, the website and other BCS social media places.

In all things, we should give thanks, so take time to thank your teachers, Principals and others who have worked so hard to get ready for this new normal. This is NOT free time off, it’s simply virtual learning with academic packets. Your teachers are possibly balancing completing lessons with their own children while teaching you from afar, so be grateful, patient and be sure to complete your work!

Finally, I want to encourage all Bessemer families to read my FAVORITE children’s book (and watch the movie later), Wonder by R.J. Palacio. It would be so cool to see video clips of our families reading the book together!! Tag us on social media of you reading the book with your child or your children reading it to you!!!

#BeatCOVID #StayWell #StaySAFE #WeAreBessemer

Dr. Autumm M. Jeter
Superintendent

Day 3 Wild About You Wednesday!

I decided to play this one because I am a product of Jess Lanier/ Bessemer City High School

So who was my favorite teacher?

I couldn’t pick just one because each of these ladies contributed something different to my years in high school!

Nefertiti Rutledge LeBeaux I WAS ON HER ROLL FOR NONE OF HER CLASSES but I was in there everyday!! No matter where she goes she’s leaves this lasting impact on students that they’ll never forget! ❤️🎯

Sonjanika Henderson-Green this lady is HILARIOUS. I understood virtually nothing about language when she taught it because it was not my favorite subject. But I went to her class just to get on her nerves and get cursed out 😂😂

Thank you for all you do/did!

Jonesboro Elementary School
March 30 at 1:25 PM ·

Jonesboro Elementary School (JES) students and parents.

Beginning April 6th, JES will implement its e-learning plan for the remainder of the school year. In order for students and teachers to communicate effectively and for students to complete online assignments, students need access to technology.

JES faculty and staff will distribute laptops to students in grades 2-5 from 9:00 a.m. until 12:00 p.m. on Friday, April 3rd.

Here is the distribution protocol:

1)Drive up to the school and someone will greet you outside. 2)A staff member will show you the computer, charging cord, and technology use form.
3)Open your trunk, and the staff member will place the items in your trunk.
4)Pull forward and close your trunk.

In order for all parties to remain safe, all parties must keep safe distances. Devices must be returned before the end of the school year.
